Award.AwardTitle: Dimensions: Integrating dimensions of Solanum biodiversity: leveraging comparative and experimental transcriptomics to understand functional responses to environmental change
Award.AbstractNarration:
Responses to environmental variation and change can be facilitated or constrained by the genetic basis of adaptations that mediate organism-environment interactions. This research aims to understand and interpret the genetics of functional adaptive biodiversity by integrating analyses at multiple levels of functional trait variation (DNA sequence, gene expression, phenotypes) with data on the environmental, ecological, and evolutionary history of an entire clade of species: Solanum section Lycopersicum (the wild tomatoes). The project focuses on two traits critical to plant-environment interactions: leaf ecophysiology (which influences plant responses to water, light, and carbon dioxide), and constitutive and induced defense responses (which influence the interaction between plants and their natural predators). Both traits differ within and among Solanum species, likely as the result of rapid adaptive change. Using 'next generation' sequencing technologies to quantify DNA sequence and gene expression differences among genotypes and environmental conditions, the project has three components: 1) Comparative transcriptomics (i.e., gene expression profiling) which will provide a evolutionary genomics framework for understanding genetic variation in the group, and identify candidate genes for important ecological transitions among species; 2) Experimental transcriptomics of gene expression responses to both benign (unstressed; noninduced) and stressed (drought-stressed; induced defense) conditions, which will identify molecular responses to ecologically-relevant environments, and evaluate the genetic constraints on current and future evolutionary responses critical to organism-environment interactions; and 3) Integration of results from this study with existing data to generate a core set of loci underpinning functional responses to abiotic and biotic environmental variation, and to develop an integrated understanding of natural adaptive trait variation across an entire group of species.

Global environmental change is expected to fundamentally alter patterns of biodiversity, but predicting the direction and magnitude of this change is extremely difficult. This research aims to understand how current biodiversity is shaped by, and reacts to, environmental variation. The sequence and trait data uncovered will contribute to understanding how plants are able to respond to and cope with stress imposed by both their physical environment and by their predators. The project will also contribute to human resources by training researchers in a broad set of skills at the interface of experimental genetics, genomics, and bioinformatics. This research focuses on the wild tomatoes, a diverse group of Andean species within the economically important genus Solanum. Uncovering the genetic basis of diversification is particularly pertinent in the Andean biological hotspot, where the impacts of land-use and climate change threaten a cradle of biodiversity that holds an estimated 12% of global flowering plant diversity. In addition, by examining the wild relatives of several important crop species, including tomato, potato, and pepper, this research has the potential to identify valuable natural variation that confers plant tolerance to critical environmental stresses.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of the funded research was to generate an integrated understanding of natural adaptive trait variation in response to abiotic and biotic environmental variation in the plant group Solanum sect. Lycopersicon (the closest wild relatives of the domesticated tomato). 

First, using patterns of genetic variation inferred from >50% of all expressed genes in the tomato genome, the research examined phylogenomic relationships among all species in this group, and inferred the major sources of genetic variation fueling adaptive differences among them. The research uncovered several striking patterns that indicate the wild tomato group has undergone very recent rapid diversification: Species have extensive shared genetic variation and low genome-wide DNA sequence divergence, and there is widespread disagreement between the histories described by individual gene trees versus the species tree. These patterns are signatures of rapid, consecutive, lineage-splitting events. On this background of complex genetic relationships, the research identified evidence for three major sources of potentially adaptive genetic variation: gene transfer via post-speciation hybridization, new lineage-specific mutations, and ancestral genetic variation present at the origin of the group.

Second, focusing on specific tissues and ecologically-relevant phenotypes (herbivore defense, drought response) in a diverse subset of genotypes, the research examined the molecular and physiological basis of adaptive phenotypes using patterns of gene expression and trait variation. The research findings indicate that heritable molecular and physiological stress responses are associated with relevant ecological variation: clusters of differentially-expressed genes co-vary with key molecular regulators in stress-responsive genotypes but not in unresponsive genotypes, and the distribution of genetic changes causing ecophysiological differences between species is consistent with divergence due to natural selection. In addition, even closely-related species have large differences in defense and drought physiology, indicating these phenotypes are both highly labile across short timescales, and potential responsive to local ecological conditions.

Third, newly generated and existing data on gene expression, DNA sequence variation, genetic mapping of quantitative traits, and ecophysiological response variation, were integrated with genome-wide data on historical relationships across the group of wild tomato species. To do so, several new analyses, computational pipelines, and visualization tools were developed; these tools can also be applied to similar datasets by other researchers in the future. These analyses were used to infer the history and timing of origin of adaptive trait variation, to assess the relationship between adaptation to alternative (abiotic and biotic) axes of environmental variation, and to identify genes that are strong candidates for causing adaptive physiological responses to climate and environmental variation. These candidates will be the target of future functional studies to confirm these hypothesized roles.

 

The research generated several large, unique datasets (now publically archived) that provide diverse opportunities for the broader research community to examine genome-wide DNA sequence, gene expression, and trait variation within and between wild tomato species. These data can be used for the discovery and exploitation of economically-useful natural genetic variation in crop-wild relatives.

These research projects also provided a diverse training environment for undergraduates, graduate students, technicians, and a postdoc, in approaches and methods relevant to physiology, evolutionary biology, phylogenetic methods, and genomics.  The participation of underrepresented groups was prioritized via formal and informal recruitment programs. The research also contributed to developing educational tools for understanding and explaining plant biology, biodiversity, and biological experimentation. Broader outreach included site visits to elementary schools. In addition, a dedicated website was developed to highlight natural trait variation among the wild relatives of domesticated tomato. The website includes an interactive web-based interface for searching and displaying wild tomato geographical distributions in an interactive map, based on known collection data.
